qas.question: About whom was Elizabeth worried in the 1970s?
What was the subject under consideration in discussions in 1980?
What did patriation of the Canadian Constitution remove from the constitution?
What was retained in the constitution?
What did Trudeau say Elizabeth favored?
In what year did Pierre Trudeau become the Canadian prime minister?
Who was one of the Canadians politicians sent to London in 1980?
In what year did Bill C-60 fail?
In what year did Pierre Trudeau cease to be Canada's prime minister?
Who was the prime minister of Britain in 1980?

context: According to Paul Martin, Sr., by the end of the 1970s the Queen was worried that the Crown "had little meaning for" <a0_0><b6_0><b9_0>Pierre Trudeau<b9_0/><b6_0/><a0_0/>, the Canadian Prime Minister. Tony Benn said that the Queen found Trudeau "rather disappointing". Trudeau's supposed republicanism seemed to be confirmed by his antics, such as sliding down banisters at Buckingham Palace and pirouetting behind the Queen's back in <b5_0>1977<b5_0/>, and the removal of various Canadian royal symbols during his term of office. In <b7_0><b8_0>1980<b8_0/><b7_0/>, Canadian politicians sent to London to discuss the patriation of the <a1_0>Canadian constitution<a1_0/> found the Queen "better informed ... than any of the British politicians or bureaucrats". She was particularly interested after the failure of Bill C-60, which would have affected her role as head of state. Patriation removed the role of the <a2_0>British parliament<a2_0/> from the Canadian constitution, but the <a3_0>monarchy<a3_0/> was retained. Trudeau said in his memoirs that the Queen favoured his attempt to <a4_0>reform<a4_0/> the constitution and that he was impressed by "the grace she displayed in public" and "the wisdom she showed in private".
